body: Yes, I don't also think people use old versions(e.g. 1.4) in NB. We should be able to remove the unnecessary code (for checking version) if NB would provide support for old Java versions no longer. Just in case, I left them as it is :)

> But we also could have replaced the old code with StringBuilder and call it a day.

Given JEP 280 wouldn't that be the wrong approach?  Actually, I'm dubious about this PR.

Hm, interesting remark. So in this case leaving the + is best as the
compiler takes care of everything.

There is on case where using stringbuilder might be nice: as a first
version that gets modified by hand, for example to conditionally append
some text. I suspect in that case the compiler will create multiple
stringbuilder while in our case the user would remove a line a replace it
with an if.

In this situation we need that checkbox.

--emi

Am Donnerstag, den 06.06.2019, 15:38 -0700 schrieb Eirik Bakke:
> As for SVG files, at least these particular ones, I prefer to regard
> them as opaque files that shouldn't be hand-edited, since they will
> be re-generated by Adobe Illustrator every time we make changes to
> the icons. 

This raises the question whether Adobe Illustrator is the right tool. I
don't know the ratio of people having access to Adobe Illustrator, but
I would prefer tools directly working on the SVG code.

If needed for example with pure SVG code, we could transform the files
at build time and strip comments and so on.

However, Apache is pretty clear, that files, that can carry the license
header should (very hard should) carry it. For SVG files this is the
case. If Adobe Illustrator is not able to add a fixed comment
(apparantly it can, as there is already one), additional tooling needs
to do it (adding an XML comment will not be hard).

> (Besides, SVG icons, which are loaded at runtime, will become about
> 25% larger on average if we add a license comment to each. Not sure
> it really matters.)

Depends - I tested the raw parsing speed (file -> DOM) and got a
penalty of about 5% (undo.svg with and without comment). For
transcoding to PNG I got a penalty of 4%. With caching this is a one-
off problem. Seinng the SVG-PNG comparison, this speed problem looks
not significant.

The size itself IMHO is not problem - if it is, run the files through
gzip and decompress von the fly.


Am Samstag, den 08.06.2019, 20:41 -0700 schrieb Jaroslav Tulach:
> > I'm curious which apps use the platform and would use a modern
> > Apache NetBeans Platform
> > version but wouldn't want to support HiDPI screens?
> 
> ... we are talking about the NetBeans Runtime Container. People like
> @jlahoda, @tzezula and @sdedic spent a significant amount of time
> making sure NetBeans modules can be used in a headless mode. We are
> not going to ruin such efforts just because we want SVG icons.

That arguement does not cut it. There is net.java.html.* already in the
platform. The same argument would cut there, as they are surely not
running headless.

> That arguement does not cut it. There is net.java.html.* already in the
platform. The same argument would cut there, as they are surely not
running headless.

Except net.java.html.* is not in the NetBeans Runtime Container.

Not sure if lacking SVG for the splash screen is much of a problem?  And there was another discussion about changing splash implementation recently.

I had a quick look for lighter weight SVG options under suitable licenses - nothing in just one class, but did find https://github.com/blackears/svgSalamander Haven't tried it!

Am Sonntag, den 09.06.2019, 10:01 -0700 schrieb Neil C Smith:
> I had a quick look for lighter weight SVG options under suitable
> licenses - nothing in just one class, but did find 
> https://github.com/blackears/svgSalamander Haven't tried it!

I only had a quick look at it in the past. At that time it lacked CSS
base font support. My gut feeling is, that there is a reason, that
batik has the size it does.

> My gut feeling is, that there is a reason, that batik has the size it does.

Yes, but I'm going on the basis that's probably a lot of features not needed for icons?

Of course, another option might be compile-time class generation from SVG using Photon from https://github.com/kirill-grouchnikov/radiance ?  Closer to @timboudreau suggestion above?

I'll make sure to put Batik support in an optional module so it's not part of the core runtime container.

If it's required, I'm fine with putting licenses in the SVG files. (Alternatively we could use SVGZ instead, which is just a gzipped SVG file--clearly a binary file...)

The tool to use for drawing icons is really up to whoever volunteers their time or money to draw them. Though ideally we want people with some graphic design experience to draw icons--and among those people Adobe Illustrator is pretty standard.

> However expect troubles at early stages of startup - for example you couldn't use SVG to render splash screen...

Yes, the proposed HiDPI splash screen code takes another approach for this, using PNG instead. (See separate PR at https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1246 . The ScaledBitmapIcon class in the latter PR will be simplified a bit once this PR is merged and CachedHiDPIIcon becomes a public class that it can extend from.)

Am Sonntag, den 09.06.2019, 12:05 -0700 schrieb Eirik Bakke:
> If it's required, I'm fine with putting licenses in the SVG files.
> (Alternatively we could use SVGZ instead, which is just a gzipped SVG
> file--clearly a binary file...)

We wan't to be good citizens of the Apache eco system, we should not
unnessarily stretch the rules (a nitpicker would tell you, that you can
gzip at build time ...).
Merged via https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/fb016919734b98643341c01c5f720d205e48ecff - thank you.
Adding API change label since this PR adds new properties that can be added to the branding file to set the location of the version string on the splash screen.
The change makes sense. Merged via https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/b4f8d19733318daff1b3d3fc538a1493b8b02bbe. Thank you.
Makes sense. +1 from me.

Thanks for the review.

I'm not sure if one item should be in the palette by default, maybe best to leave it completely empty. I would like to think more about this and I think we should not include this in 11.1, marking it for 11.2.
Added NB11.1 label.  Would love to get this merged this week so I don't have to faff around with splash screens during the release process! :smile:
Added a comment on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2455 to see if there's consensus on this approach.
Just merge it unless there’d be any reason to disagree with this.
Awesome, I approve. :-)
Merging, no reason not to do so.
Maybe we should include the 8.2 update center (disabled) so that C/C++ can be installed?

I very much agree on having this in NB11.1, even off-by-default.

Parameter names and in general in-line dynamic editor annotations/helpers are hype in competitor IDEs. This would allow to show that NB is not lagging behind.

If I am not mistaken from Java 8 upwards the compiler is able to use `StringBuilder` under the hood for simple string concatenation like that generated by NB in toString implementations out of a handful of class member variables.

Explicit use of `StringBuilder` is recommended when concatenating string literals in a loop.

See [here](http://www.pellegrino.link/2015/08/22/string-concatenation-with-java-8.html) for a deepest analysis and some benchmarks.

To sum up this modification will be beneficial for those on Java 6 and 7 from a performance point of view

@AlexFalappa and would be potentially detrimental for anyone on Java 9+ - see [here](https://dzone.com/articles/jdk-9jep-280-string-concatenations-will-never-be-t).  I'm pretty sure the StringBuilder optimization in javac predates Java 8 too.

So, this might make sense as an option, but probably not the default or something to encourage.
Looks sane to me too.
@mcdonnell-john should we mark this as work in progress?
Yep. My laptop broke a while back and only got a replacement this week. I'm looking at the changes to driver and datasource classes at the moment but won't make 11.1
Will merge Friday, before feature freeze... just wanted to give David Schulz a chance to provide updated splash screen artwork, so I don't "overwrite" his work.
I propose we go ahead with this pull request and open a new issue for the better approach described by @jtulach. If no problem with this in 24 hours, I will merge this.
There seems to be a problem here, though would be great to merge this for 11.1.
There seems to be a problem here, though would be great to merge this for 11.1.
Is there any reason not to merge this, what part of this needs to be especially reviewed?
Great, merging this.
Neat. Any reason not to merge this? Feel free to merge this yourself, unless you are convinced a review is needed first.
Or, it seems to be off by default already? If so, let's merge this.
All jobs are failing at **Installing oraclejdk8** or **Setting environment variables from .travis.yml** phase.
This one's low-risk, applies only to Windows 10, which I have tried it on, and any bugs are likely to be purely cosmetic in nature. Merging after reading through it once again myself....
Awesome, let's get it in for 11.1. :-)

I wonder what is the advantage of someone generating the toString with explicit StringBuilders? Isn't that what (for 5 <= JDK <=8) javac will produce itself?

If someone wants to customize the toString in such a way that the StringBuilder would help, would including a possibility to expand string concatenation to StringBuilder in the Alt-Enter popup help more?

Anyway, as this is default off, and tested, I don't have strong objections, but I don't see a strong reason for this either. Sorry.

I've added this because it seems that other IDEs has a feature like this. This doesn't mean making people use StringBuilder forcibly. Up to users whether it is used. (The checkbox is unchecked by default.)

Ideas:
- Never add this feature
or
- Add the checkbox when 5 <= version <= 8
or
- Add the checkbox always

I don't have a strong opinion we really need this, but in any case, we should add unit tests because currently, there is no unit test for this generator :)
OK, should we go ahead and merge this?
Can this be fixed, please?
OK, then. Merging.
@eirikbakke, I leave this to you to merge, OK?
OK, merging.
Ready to merge this for 11.1?
Any reason not to merge this? Feel free to merge, @rtaneja1.

Wow, this is exactly what we need for each language. I wanted to try to achieve that, but I didn't know how to create virtual text or readonly text inside the editor. Is there an public API/documentation for creating such virtual text to makes it easier @jlahoda?
Should this PR be closed or what’s the plan here?

There seems to be some infra issue with travis, build failing in bin/install-jdk.sh for other PRs as well with same errors
Expected feature release number in range of 9 to 13, but got: 8
^[[31;1mThe command "~/bin/install-jdk.sh --target "/home/travis/oraclejdk8" --workspace "/home/travis/.cache/install-jdk" --feature "8" --license "BCL"" failed and exited with 3 during .^[[0m

Checking who owns install-jdk.sh

@neilcsmith-net I was pointing out that this feature is useful to a limited user audience but unharmful if off by default.

I personally prefer to use Benno Marckiewitz _Additional Java Hints_ plugin that offer a group of hints aimed at transforming between concatenation, `StringBuilder`, `StringBuffer` and other neat things. I am able to consciously use `StringBuilder` when I really need.

@AlexFalappa and I was only pointing out that your comment about concatenation in a loop and benchmark links may be inaccurate for Java 9+, and the performance comment for 6 and 7 is wrong - hence interest in @jlahoda opinion.  Personally, I think that fully generated methods should be legible and performant defaults, and this would complicate the UI and fail at both.  Perhaps you, I and Jan actually agree that hints would be the correct way to approach this use case when the end user does want to customize the generated code?!
Actually everything is working, I think this PR could be closed.
Done. If we get new splash screen artwork but it's after the feature freeze it can just go in the following version.
Great job.
@jkovalsky this appears to have broken the daily build ability to download nb-javac, etc.  The linked update center doesn't exist (yet)?!

@neilcsmith-net I understood your reasoning.

Agreed on the use of hints.
I'm trying, though I'm not a Travis expert....

@eirikbakke great! :+1: Personally, I don't think there's a problem with merging new artwork after feature freeze if people want it.  At the same time, I prefer your artwork anyway - it's cleaner and more legible.

One possible enhancement for this might be to also consider screen resolution in deciding splash size?  I have a large 2560x1440 display, but with DPI scaling set to 1.  Still be nice to have larger splash on such a setup.
I'm going to add the API increase and some docs, but will be merged today to be ready for 11.1
Thanks, let me know how I should proceed now that Travis build failed.  I appreciate your time.

Build passes here
https://builds.apache.org/view/M-R/view/NetBeans/job/netbeans-installers/

For the build failures on travis, please rebase onto current master. @lkishalmi switched the builds to OpenJDK in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/87c2a53c28a6e365bd75203100ddd3e77ce8e23b, that should fix your issue.
Thanks @matthiasblaesing I appreciate your humble assistance, as always.  I believe I've re-based properly...let's see if Travis is happy now.
I see no reason not to merge, and we need this, so I am merging.
Any reason not to merge this?
What is the status of this?
If travis checks out green then this shall go into master then to 11.1
Probably it is better not to allow such a situation. Closing it now.
I do not see any.

This is much more work than expected. More than 1300 license headers pending to be reviewed and fixed individually, one by one. Even after a couple of improvements on the conversion tool. 
We need it, esp. the german language pack, and I still feel committed to it. I can't resume work on it before July 20.

> One possible enhancement for this might be to also consider screen resolution in deciding splash size? I have a large 2560x1440 display, but with DPI scaling set to 1. Still be nice to have larger splash on such a setup.

That would be a simple change to make. Feel free to open a JIRA issue for it. It should be done after the PR at https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1278 gets merged, because the latter can make all the caching logic in ScaledBitmapIcon.java go into a superclass (I will make said simplification as part of that other PR).
@borisheithecker thank you for working on this! I'll mark this PR as work-in-progress, so that people know the state.
Merged via https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/8facebfce84017a66ae2b50d079ed3e7652604c9. Thank you.
And the update center has been already created yesterday. Now we need to get the nb-javac plugin to the Maven Central repository. @jlahoda can you please take care of that?

Sorry, there's some info missing on my end -- what is the update center URL, how does it work together with Maven Central now, and where exactly should the co-ordinates for nb-javac be registered, assuming we can upload nb-javac to Maven Central?

This also appears to be a problem for Apache NetBeans 11.0, somehow, i.e., not just for the daily build -- can we do what is needed to get the current release, i.e., 11.0, to correctly access nb-javac and the Oracle JS Parser? Or should that not be impacted by this?
The Travis CI fails: Please try merging the latest master branch( or rebasing  with the latest master branch), then try pushing again. (if you rebase your branch, maybe need force option `-f`)
No, this does not have any influence on Apache NetBeans 11.0. I verified myself that I could install both Oracle JS Parser and nb-javac plugins smoothly.

@junichi11 

Waiting for your feedback, please let me know. I am ready to merge it as it is now, of course.

*Note:* If I see something really small that could be perhaps improved, I usually create a comment for it and directly resolve it because I don't want to block merging with such a tiny thing :)

Thanks!
But why must nb-javac be uploaded to Maven Central? Why not the same as always before? And why is ‘experimental’ in the name of the update center?

Having nb-javac in Maven Central rather than on Oracle infra sounds a positive move.  Would agree with removing "experimental" from the UC name though.

What are we doing about UC for nb-javac, etc. in 11.1 - going back to same as 11.0 or using this?

> But why must nb-javac be uploaded to Maven Central? Why not the same as always before?

Because we want to get rid of the Plugin Portal 2.0 hosted on Oracle infra and rather use Plugin Portal 3.0 hosted on Apache infra.

> And why is ‘experimental’ in the name of the update center?

Because the plugins on that update center are not verified.
@tmysik I really appreciate your review always! I'll fix pointed out parts later. Thanks a lot, Tomas!

> What are we doing about UC for nb-javac, etc. in 11.1 - going back to same as 11.0 or using this?

For 11.1 I thought we would rely on the same source as for 11.0 i.e. Plugin Portal 2.0

We need nb-javac and Oracle JS Parser to be in an update center dedicated to 11.1 (or maybe not, i.e., not if they are not different to what we're using in 11.0), we do not want to host them in Maven Central (we don't know how to do that yet), i.e., it should all be as similar to 11.0 as possible for 11.1, I think.

Surely that's an orthogonal issue?  The UC catalog location doesn't affect whether we use Maven Central to serve the plugins from.  There would probably be benefits to using the intended future location in 11.1.  But if I need to switch this back in the release branch, please let me know.

@junichi11 

Nothing to thank for, really. Kudos to you for implementing the support!

> > And why is ‘experimental’ in the name of the update center?
> 
> Because the plugins on that update center are not verified.

Such as what, for example, i.e., which plugins will be in this update center?
Fixed :)

@junichi11 

Thanks a lot! I need to leave now so feel free to merge this PR yourself once CI passes (or I will do it but tomorrow).
@tmysik OK, will do.

> Such as what, for example, i.e., which plugins will be in this update center?

http://plugins.netbeans.org/nbpluginportal/updates/11.0/catalog-experimental.xml
CCing @entlicher

> But if I need to switch this back in the release branch, please let me know.

If I understand https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/Release+Schedule correctly, the 11.1 release branch will be created from master, won't it? In such case you will have to update the mf-layer.xml and Bundle.properties file to contain the same values as their 11.0 versions. If 11.1 is branched from 11.0 no such change is obviously needed.
We're meant to be in feature freeze!  The release branch was made today.  Is this ready and intended to be merged into NB11.1?

@neilcsmith-net No, We are going to provide support for PHP7.4 in NetBeans 11.2 because PHP 7.4 has not been released yet :) PHP 7.4 will be released in Nov. https://wiki.php.net/todo/php74 Thank you for asking it!

@junichi11 in which case it should probably not be in master yet!  Everything in master is being merged to the release.  Not sure best thing to do now - is this safe to be in NB11.1?  If not, we'll need to revert.

@neilcsmith-net You have already created the new branch for NB11.1. This PR is not needed to merge into that branch. So I think there is no problem. If needed, you should cherry-pick changes into the branch for NB11.1, I suppose.
@junichi11 we're not cherry picking - everything going into master is synced across - that was the revised release plan that was agreed to!
